feed.title: Management of new onset atrial fibrillation

section.label: Important first steps
section.fragment: A complete history and physical examination should be performed in all patients with new onset AF.

section.label: INDICATIONS FOR URGENT CARDIOVERSION
section.fragment: The presence of a preexcitation syndrome, which may lead to an extremely rapid ventricular rate due to the presence of an accessory pathway.

section.label: INDICATIONS FOR URGENT CARDIOVERSION
section.fragment: In a patient with any of these indications for urgent cardioversion, the need for restoration of normal sinus rhythm (NSR) takes precedence over the need for protection from thromboembolic risk.

section.label: INDICATIONS FOR URGENT CARDIOVERSION
section.fragment: Further, indiscriminate cardioversion may have dire consequences or be futile if the cause for the initiation of the problem is not at least in part corrected (eg, immediate cardioversion in a patient with pulmonary edema will be dangerous to the patient and may not be effective without diuresis, oxygen, blood pressure control and other measures).

section.label: INDICATIONS FOR URGENT CARDIOVERSION
section.fragment: Cardioversion of patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) is discussed elsewhere.

section.label: EVALUATION FOR AN UNDERLYING CAUSE
section.fragment: When faced with a patient who presents with new onset atrial fibrillation (AF) (particularly if the ventricular response is rapid), there should be a quick assessment for an underlying cause, such as heart failure (HF), pulmonary problems, poorly controlled blood pressure, or hyperthyroidism.

section.label: EVALUATION FOR AN UNDERLYING CAUSE
section.fragment: Therapy for a precipitating cause should be initiated prior to cardioversion in stable patients and may result in reversion to sinus rhythm.

section.label: EVALUATION FOR AN UNDERLYING CAUSE
section.fragment: The following tests, in addition to the electrocardiogram, should be performed on patients with new onset AF: Vital signs including oxygen saturation (in the ER setting and beyond).

section.label: EVALUATION FOR AN UNDERLYING CAUSE
section.fragment: These should be obtained even if there are no symptoms suggestive of hyperthyroidism (and if thyroid function has not been measured recently), since the risk of AF is increased up to threefold in patients with subclinical hyperthyroidism ).

section.label: EVALUATION FOR AN UNDERLYING CAUSE
section.fragment: The latter disorder is characterized by low serum TSH (<0.5 mU/L with the newer sensitive assays) and normal serum free T4.

section.label: EVALUATION FOR AN UNDERLYING CAUSE
section.fragment: A transthoracic echocardiogram should be performed to screen for cardiac causes of new onset atrial fibrillation, even in the face of a normal physical examination.

section.label: EVALUATION FOR AN UNDERLYING CAUSE
section.fragment: AF is rarely the only manifestation of an acute coronary syndrome, although AF with a rapid ventricular response and hypotension can provoke demand ischemia with or without angina.

section.label: EVALUATION FOR AN UNDERLYING CAUSE
section.fragment: We suggest evaluation of myocardial infarction with serial troponin measurements, especially in patients with electrocardiogram (ECG) changes, hypotension, symptoms, history, or additional risk factors.

section.label: ANTICOAGULATION
section.fragment: This section will address the role of antithrombotic therapy in patients with new onset AF.

section.label: ANTICOAGULATION
section.fragment: The larger discussions of anticoagulation surrounding cardioversion and recommendations for the use of long-term antithrombotic therapy in patients with more than one episode of atrial fibrillation (AF) are found elsewhere.

section.label: Patients requiring delayed cardioversion
section.fragment: In these patients, it is preferable to anticoagulate and use transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) to rule out left atrial thrombi.

section.label: Patients requiring delayed cardioversion
section.fragment: While there is little published evidence that the risk of embolization after planned (either chemical or electric) cardioversion is greater than after spontaneous reversion, some of our authors and reviewers are concerned that delayed return of atrial mechanical function (atrial stunning) after electrical cardioversion could increase the risk of a thromboembolic event after this approach with cardioversion.

section.label: Patients requiring delayed cardioversion
section.fragment: When warfarin is chosen as the anticoagulant, the recommended target International Normalized Ratio (INR) is 2.5 (range 2.0 to 3.0).

section.label: Role of TEE
section.fragment: This regimen may be of particular use in the patient who requires hospitalization or has an increased risk of hemorrhagic complications during prolonged anticoagulant therapy.

section.label: Role of TEE
section.fragment: The ACUTE trial directly compared a TEE-guided strategy (anticoagulation with heparin immediately before TEE or with oral warfarin for five days [target INR 2.0 to 3.0] before TEE, followed by cardioversion and then warfarin for four weeks after cardioversion), with a conventional strategy (three weeks of anticoagulation before cardioversion, followed by four weeks of anticoagulation after cardioversion) in 1222 patients with AF of more than two days' duration who were undergoing electrical cardioversion.

section.label: Early cardioversion or spontaneous reversion
section.fragment: With the exception of certain high-risk patients, the embolic risk appears to be very low if cardioversion is performed within two days of the onset of AF.

section.label: Early cardioversion or spontaneous reversion
section.fragment: The logic for doing so is that the risk of bleeding from anticoagulation is probably greater than the risk of embolization (particularly in those with CHADS2 scores of 0 or 1), and the risk of thromboembolic events from short duration of atrial fibrillation appears to be relatively low (but not zero).

section.label: Early cardioversion or spontaneous reversion
section.fragment: In addition, our authors and reviewers differ on the approach to long-term anticoagulation in these patients, with some suggesting no oral anticoagulation for the first episode of AF (less than 48 hours duration) and others suggesting warfarin or a novel oral anticoagulant for patients with CHADS2/CHA2DS2-VASc scores of two or greater.

section.label: Early cardioversion or spontaneous reversion
section.fragment: Guidelines from the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association and the American College of Chest Physicians suggest periprocedural heparin in patients with new onset AF of less than 48 hours duration, but make weak recommendations against the use of prolonged anticoagulation (three weeks).

section.label: Early cardioversion or spontaneous reversion
section.fragment: The 2011 European Society of Cardiology guidelines for the management of AF make a weak recommendation for periprocedural heparin in all such patients, as well as long-term oral anticoagulant in patients at high risk of stroke.

section.label: Early cardioversion or spontaneous reversion
section.fragment: Our authors and reviewers believe it is reasonable to defer cardioversion and start oral anticoagulation in selected patients with AF of less than 48 hours in whom cardioversion is planned.

section.label: INITIAL RATE CONTROL WITH MILD TO MODERATE SYMPTOMS
section.fragment: In patients with mild to moderate symptoms, concurrent with the initiation of the appropriate anticoagulation treatment, the initial therapy includes slowing the ventricular rate without an immediate strategy to restore sinus rhythm.

section.label: INITIAL RATE CONTROL WITH MILD TO MODERATE SYMPTOMS
section.fragment: As noted above, this can be achieved with beta blockers, calcium channel blockers (primarily verapamil and diltiazem), and/or digoxin.

section.label: INITIAL RATE CONTROL WITH MILD TO MODERATE SYMPTOMS
section.fragment: Occasionally, intravenous (IV) amiodarone may be needed for patients with poor left ventricular function.

section.label: INITIAL RATE CONTROL WITH MILD TO MODERATE SYMPTOMS
section.fragment: Beta blockers or verapamil or diltiazem are the preferred drugs in the absence of heart failure (HF), since digoxin is less likely to control the ventricular rate during exercise (when vagal tone is low and sympathetic tone is high), has little ability to terminate the arrhythmia, and often does not slow the heart rate in patients with recurrent atrial fibrillation (AF).

section.label: INITIAL RATE CONTROL WITH MILD TO MODERATE SYMPTOMS
section.fragment: Digoxin is the preferred drug only in patients with AF due to HF.

section.label: INITIAL RATE CONTROL WITH MILD TO MODERATE SYMPTOMS
section.fragment: In addition to the direct vagotonic effect of digoxin on the atrioventricular (AV) node (which may require several hours to become apparent), the improvement in left ventricular function and systemic hemodynamics result in withdrawal of sympathetic tone and a further decrease in the ventricular rate.

section.label: INITIAL RATE CONTROL WITH MILD TO MODERATE SYMPTOMS
section.fragment: Digoxin can also be used in patients who cannot take or who respond inadequately to beta blockers or calcium channel blockers.

section.label: INITIAL RATE CONTROL WITH MILD TO MODERATE SYMPTOMS
section.fragment: The effect of digoxin is additive to both of these drugs.

section.label: INITIAL RATE CONTROL WITH MILD TO MODERATE SYMPTOMS
section.fragment: IV AV nodal blockers, in particular digoxin and verapamil, are contraindicated in patients with atrial fibrillation and preexcitation.

section.label: INITIAL RATE CONTROL WITH MILD TO MODERATE SYMPTOMS
section.fragment: On the other hand, a calcium channel blocker is preferred in patients with chronic lung disease.

section.label: CARDIOVERSION
section.fragment: The next step after control of the ventricular rate in patients with recent onset atrial fibrillation (AF), who are hemodynamically stable (with only mild to moderate symptoms), is deciding whether an attempt will be made to cardiovert the patient and if so when.

section.label: CARDIOVERSION
section.fragment: We believe that most patients with symptomatic new onset atrial fibrillation should have at least one attempt at cardioversion (either electrical or chemical) to sinus rhythm, particularly after reversible causes have been identified and corrected.

section.label: CARDIOVERSION
section.fragment: cardioversion will likely improve symptom status, particularly in young people.

section.label: CARDIOVERSION
section.fragment: Circumstances in which it is reasonable to not attempt cardioversion in a patient with new onset AF include: Patients who are completely asymptomatic, particularly those who are very elderly (>80 years) with multiple comorbidities, where risks of undergoing cardioversion and/or pharmacologic rhythm control may outweigh the benefits of restoring sinus rhythm.

section.label: CARDIOVERSION
section.fragment: There is a low risk of systemic embolization if the duration of the arrhythmia is 24 hours or less (and the risks are acceptable up to 48 hours) and there are no cardiac abnormalities (particularly mitral valve disease or significant left ventricular enlargement due to a cardiomyopathy) on transthoracic echocardiography.

section.label: CARDIOVERSION
section.fragment: Most patients with new onset AF of longer than 48 hours duration should have cardioversion postponed.

section.label: CARDIOVERSION
section.fragment: For patients with paroxysmal episodes of atrial fibrillation, drug therapy is preferred if they will have sinus rhythm maintained with long-term antiarrhythmic drug therapy, and as patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation will likely convert anyway with or without electrical cardioversion.

section.label: CARDIOVERSION
section.fragment: In some patients, antiarrhythmic drugs are administered prior to cardioversion to increase the chance of successful reversion and to prevent early, intermediate, and late recurrence ).

section.label: Antiarrhythmic therapy after reversion to sinus rhythm
section.fragment: We agree with the American Association of Family Physicians/American College of Physicians (AAFP/ACP) guideline recommendation that maintenance antiarrhythmic drug therapy not be routinely used after cardioversion in patients with newly detected AF.

section.label: Spontaneous reversion of AF
section.fragment: The optimal antithrombotic therapy after spontaneous cardioversion of a first episode of AF (lasting less than 48 hours) in patients without structural heart disease is discussed above.

section.label: INDICATIONS FOR HOSPITALIZATION
section.fragment: Many patients with new onset atrial fibrillation (AF), particularly those without spontaneous reversion, have often been admitted to the hospital.

section.label: INDICATIONS FOR HOSPITALIZATION
section.fragment: Possible indications for hospitalization in patients with new onset AF are: Initiation of heparin or other anticoagulant therapy.

section.label: INDICATIONS FOR HOSPITALIZATION
section.fragment: Patients in whom ablation of an accessory pathway is being considered, particularly if the AF was highly symptomatic and associated with hemodynamic collapse and rapid ventricular response rate.

section.label: INDICATIONS FOR HOSPITALIZATION
section.fragment: The elderly are more likely to have comorbidities that can complicate drug management in the treatment of atrial fibrillation, whether it be rate control or rhythm control approaches.

section.label: DISCHARGE FROM THE EMERGENCY ROOM
section.fragment: For those patients who do not have one of the above clear indications for hospitalization, an important initial issue is whether patients presenting with new onset atrial fibrillation (AF) (less than 48 hours duration) can be managed (including cardioversion) in the emergency department or an observational unit and then discharged.

section.label: DISCHARGE FROM THE EMERGENCY ROOM
section.fragment: This issue was addressed in a study of 289 such patients who were stable, did not have heart disease, and did not have another indication for hospital admission.

section.label: DISCHARGE FROM THE EMERGENCY ROOM
section.fragment: Similar results were noted in another report of 51 patients who underwent attempted pharmacologic cardioversion with intravenous ibutilide, followed by electrical reversion if AF was still present.

section.label: DISCHARGE FROM THE EMERGENCY ROOM
section.fragment: Thus, emergency department or observational unit treatment of new onset AF in clinically stable patients, who have no other important comorbidities such as underlying structural heart disease, is safe and cost-effective.

section.label: UP
section.fragment: Routine follow-up after an episode of acute atrial fibrillation is necessary to evaluate the safety and efficacy of antiarrhythmic and anticoagulant therapies, to reassess the need for these therapies, and to assess the functional status of the patient.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: The early steps in the management of a patient with new onset atrial fibrillation (AF) involve an assessment of the need for cardioversion, rate slowing therapy, and antithrombotic therapy.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Urgent or emergent cardioversion should be considered for patients with active ischemia, significant hypotension, severe heart failure, or the presence of a preexcitation syndrome associated with rapid conduction using the accessory pathway.(See.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Most patients with symptomatic new onset atrial fibrillation should have at least one attempt at cardioversion (either electrical or chemical) to sinus rhythm, particularly after reversible causes have been identified and corrected.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Most patients with new onset AF who have sinus rhythm restored do not need maintenance antiarrhythmic drug therapy.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Our specific recommendations are as follows: We recommend rate control to improve symptoms and to reduce the risk of tachycardia-mediated cardiomyopathy for all patients who do not require urgent or emergent cardioversion.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Beta blockers and nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are preferred as first-line agents in most patients.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For patients with AF less than 48 hours in duration, the use of periprocedural heparin (or enoxaparin) to reduce the risk of embolization can be considered.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: The decision to start long-term oral anticoagulation in these patients should be made based on an assessment of the long-term risk of embolization based on the CHADS2 score.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For patients with AF of longer than 48 hours duration, we recommend four weeks of therapeutic oral anticoagulation prior to cardioversion, as opposed to immediate cardioversion.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Transesophageal echocardiography-based (TEE) screening for the presence of atrial thrombi is recommended among patients with AF of recent onset (but more than 48 hours or unknown duration) if semi-urgent cardioversion is necessary.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Possible indications for hospitalization in patients with new onset AF include (but are not limited to).

feed.title: Antiarrhythmic drugs to maintain sinus rhythm in patients with atrial fibrillation: Recommendations

section.label: INDICATIONS
section.fragment: There are three settings in which a rhythm control strategy for the maintenance of sinus rhythm should be considered: Persistent symptoms (palpitations, dyspnea, lightheadedness, angina, syncope, and heart failure) despite adequate rate control.

section.label: INDICATIONS
section.fragment: We consider cardioversion to sinus rhythm in most patients, particularly younger patients, with a first-detected episode of atrial fibrillation (AF) in whom the arrhythmia is of recent onset and the risk for recurrence appears to be low.

section.label: INDICATIONS
section.fragment: Maintenance antiarrhythmic drug therapy is not routinely used after cardioversion in patients with newly detected AF.

section.label: Addressing precipitating factors
section.fragment: Maintenance antiarrhythmic drug therapy is not recommended after cardioversion in a patient with a transient or reversible cause (such as cardiac surgery, pericarditis, or pulmonary embolism).

section.label: AV nodal blocker therapy
section.fragment: This therapy is continued while the patient is in sinus rhythm to protect against a rapid ventricular rate (greater than 110 bpm) should AF recur.

section.label: AV nodal blocker therapy
section.fragment: A beta blocker, or rate-slowing calcium channel blocker such as verapamil or diltiazem, is often used if there are no contraindications, since the withdrawal of vagal tone and increase in sympathetic tone with exercise often render digoxin relatively ineffective for controlling the heart rate.

section.label: AV nodal blocker therapy
section.fragment: On the other hand, digoxin is often used in patients with AF associated with systolic heart failure because of its beneficial effect on symptom control.

section.label: AV nodal blocker therapy
section.fragment: Such patients are also typically treated with a beta blocker because of the associated improvement in survival.

section.label: AV nodal blocker therapy
section.fragment: The negative inotropic activity of calcium channel blockers makes them less desirable in such patients.

section.label: AV nodal blocker therapy
section.fragment: Class I antiarrhythmic drugs, such as flecainide, may suppress most, but not all, reentrant circuits.

section.label: Restoration of sinus rhythm
section.fragment: Many patients with AF in whom a rhythm control strategy is chosen will need sinus rhythm restored prior to the initiation of long-term antiarrhythmic drug therapy.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: Amiodarone, dofetilide, flecainide, propafenone, sotalol, and less commonly dronedarone are the drugs we recommend to maintain sinus rhythm.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: The following points regarding antiarrhythmic drugs should be kept in mind in choosing therapy: Compared to other agents, amiodarone is associated with the greatest likelihood of maintaining sinus rhythm, but also with the highest risk of long-term complications.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: Quinidine, procainamide, and disopyramide are no longer recommended for patients with AF, except perhaps in patients with vagally mediated atrial fibrillation (AF), as there are more effective drugs and due to extracardiac side effects as well as the concern about proarrhythmia.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: Beta blockers are modestly effective in maintaining sinus rhythm and can be tried first in selected patients, such as those without structural heart disease who are concerned about proarrhythmia.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: Of course beta blockers may have already been initiated to slow the ventricular rate in AF.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: We believe it is prudent to obtain a two-dimensional echocardiogram to screen for structural heart disease (eg, left ventricular systolic dysfunction, left ventricular hypertrophy, or valvular heart disease).

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: As examples, our experts rarely use dofetilide for paroxysmal AF and infrequently choose dronedarone for persistent AF due to reduced efficacy compared with amiodarone.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: The 2010 European Society of Cardiology and the 2006 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association/European Society of Cardiology guidelines suggest that, because of its long-lasting anticholinergic activity, disopyramide may be considered in patients with vagally-induced AF (eg, occurring most often in athletic young men with slow heart rates during rest or sleep), as long as the patient does not have prostatism or glaucoma.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: For patients with adrenergically-mediated AF (eg, occurring during exercise or other activity), we suggest beta blockers as first-line therapy, followed by sotalol and amiodarone.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: Antiarrhythmic drugs are associated with a potential for serious adverse side effects, particularly the induction of proarrhythmia.

section.label: AF without structural heart disease
section.fragment: Patients without structural heart disease include those with hypertension who do not have left ventricular hypertrophy.

section.label: AF without structural heart disease
section.fragment: The author and reviewers of this topic generally select flecainide as the first antiarrhythmic drug for these patients due to its relatively good side effect profile, efficacy, and ease of use.

section.label: AF without structural heart disease
section.fragment: In these patients, flecainide, propafenone, amiodarone, dronedarone, sotalol, and dofetilide are superior to placebo for maintaining sinus rhythm.

section.label: AF without structural heart disease
section.fragment: For those patients in whom flecainide will not be used as the preferred agent, the following points can influence the choice of antiarrhythmic drug in patients without structural heart disease: In the Canadian Trial of Atrial fibrillation, AFFIRM, and the SAFE-T randomized trials, amiodarone was more effective than flecainide, propafenone, or sotalol (which have nearly equivalent efficacy to each other), but has a significantly higher rate of adverse side effects.

section.label: AF without structural heart disease
section.fragment: In a meta-analysis of trials where the effect of amiodarone versus dronedarone was estimated with the use of indirect comparison and normal logistic meta-analysis models, amiodarone was found to be more effective in maintaining sinus rhythm, but at the expense of greater drug discontinuation secondary to adverse events.

section.label: AF without structural heart disease
section.fragment: In the EMERALD trial, Dofetilide had a somewhat better efficacy than sotalol.

section.label: AF without structural heart disease
section.fragment: Some cardiologists prefer to use low-dose amiodarone (200 mg per day) in preference to flecainide, sotalol, or dronedarone for two principal reasons: greater efficacy than sotalol and dronedarone, and a very low incidence of torsades de pointes.

section.label: AF associated with structural heart disease
section.fragment: Amiodarone, sotalol, and dofetilide are the most commonly recommended first-line drugs in patients with structural heart disease.

section.label: AF associated with structural heart disease
section.fragment: These drugs (with the exception of dronedarone) were used for initial therapy in almost 70 percent of patients in AFFIRM, 88 percent of whom had organic heart disease and/or hypertension.

section.label: AF associated with structural heart disease
section.fragment: Amiodarone was significantly more effective than sotalol in the CTAF, AFFIRM, and SAFE-T trials.

section.label: AF associated with structural heart disease
section.fragment: However, in SAFE-T, sotalol was as effective as amiodarone in the subgroup of patients with coronary heart disease.

section.label: Coronary heart disease
section.fragment: In patients with coronary heart disease who do not have heart failure, sotalol, dronedarone, dofetilide, and amiodarone are acceptable choices.

section.label: Coronary heart disease
section.fragment: In the Cardiac Arrhythmia Suppression Trial (CAST) of patients with drug-suppressible ventricular premature beats in the year following a myocardial infarction, flecainide increased mortality compared to placebo.

section.label: Coronary heart disease
section.fragment: Although propafenone was not used in CAST and may not have the same potential for proarrhythmia as flecainide and encainide, it cannot be recommended in patients with underlying heart disease.

section.label: Coronary heart disease
section.fragment: The extension of this concern to structural heart disease other than coronary artery disease stems in part from the flecainide clinical and safety database, which was used in a retrospective study demonstrating that the presence of structural heart disease including valvular heart disease, congenital heart disease, and cardiomyopathies lead to an alarming increase in proarrhythmia and death.

section.label: Heart failure
section.fragment: Amiodarone and dofetilide, are used in patients with AF and heart failure (HF) or those with a left ventricular ejection fraction less than 35 percent.

section.label: Heart failure
section.fragment: Our authors and reviewers are more comfortable using dofetilide in this setting with an implantable defibrillator in place or in younger patients with less severe impairment of left ventricular systolic function.

section.label: Heart failure
section.fragment: Sotalol, propafenone, and flecainide should not be used in patients with heart failure, due to studies showing an increase in mortality with these agents.

section.label: Left ventricular hypertrophy
section.fragment: Patients with significant left ventricular hypertrophy (defined as left ventricular wall thickness greater 1.4 cm for the purposes of this discussion) due to hypertension, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, or aortic stenosis have underlying subendocardial ischemia and electrophysiologic abnormalities.

section.label: Left ventricular hypertrophy
section.fragment: Sotalol, flecainide and propafenone are thought to have a significant arrhythmic risk in patients with left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH).

section.label: resistant AF
section.fragment: Some patients are refractory to individual antiarrhythmic agents plus an AV nodal blocker or develop side effects on doses necessary for arrhythmia prevention.

section.label: resistant AF
section.fragment: Although some have suggested that combination antiarrhythmic drug therapy (eg, a class IC agent with sotalol or amiodarone, often in lower doses) may be an alternative, there are limited data to support such an approach and the patient may be exposed to a greater risk of proarrhythmia and other side effects.

section.label: resistant AF
section.fragment: As a result, combination antiarrhythmic drug therapy is not recommended.

section.label: INPATIENT VERSUS OUTPATIENT INITIATION
section.fragment: Outpatient initiation of antiarrhythmic drug therapy with the following agents may be considered: Flecainide or propafenone in patients in sinus rhythm who have no underlying structural heart disease, normal baseline QT intervals, and no profound bradycardia or suspected sinus or atrioventricular (AV) node dysfunction.

section.label: INPATIENT VERSUS OUTPATIENT INITIATION
section.fragment: Amiodarone or dronedarone in selected patients who have no other risk factors for torsades de pointes (eg, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia) or sinus node dysfunction or AV conduction disease.

section.label: INPATIENT VERSUS OUTPATIENT INITIATION
section.fragment: Dronedarone and amiodarone are the only two drugs that can be initiated in outpatients while in atrial fibrillation.

section.label: INPATIENT VERSUS OUTPATIENT INITIATION
section.fragment: Patients with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) represent another group in which outpatient initiation of therapy can be tried, since the ICD provides protection against the risks associated with bradyarrhythmias and tachyarrhythmias.

section.label: INPATIENT VERSUS OUTPATIENT INITIATION
section.fragment: The initiation of antiarrhythmic drugs in patients with paroxysmal AF while they are in sinus rhythm is also associated with some risk.

section.label: INPATIENT VERSUS OUTPATIENT INITIATION
section.fragment: Inpatient initiation with continuous telemetry of higher-risk drugs such as dofetilide and sotalol is typically done over a course of three days, which encompasses five half-lives allowing for achievement of steady-state plasma concentrations.

section.label: AF recurrence
section.fragment: Some patients will elect to continue drug therapy (and, in some cases, occasional cardioversion) because the arrhythmia burden has been substantially reduced as evidenced by episodes that are less frequent, shorter, or associated with milder symptoms.

section.label: AF recurrence
section.fragment: Nonpharmacologic therapies are another option in such patients.

section.label: AF recurrence
section.fragment: If a patient has unacceptable recurrent AF on one antiarrhythmic drug, the drug is discontinued and another (and on rare occasion a third) agent is tried.

section.label: related arrhythmias and mortality
section.fragment: Compared to controls, the use of the class IA antiarrhythmics quinidine and disopyramide (odds ratio 2.39, 95% CI 1.03-5.59) or sotalol (2.47, 95% CI 1.2-5.05) was associated with increased all-cause mortality, whereas the use of amiodarone, dronedarone, and dofetilide was not (odds ratios were not calculated for flecainide or propafenone).

section.label: Proarrhythmia
section.fragment: All of the antiarrhythmic drugs used to maintain sinus rhythm have the potential to increase ectopy or induce or aggravate monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT), torsades de pointes, or ventricular fibrillation (VF);

section.label: Proarrhythmia
section.fragment: In addition to its baseline potential to predispose the patient to proarrhythmia, a drug that is initially safe may become proarrhythmic when the patient develops coronary heart disease or heart failure or is treated with other medications that in combination may be arrhythmogenic.

section.label: Proarrhythmia
section.fragment: Thus, the patient should be alerted to the potential significance of symptoms such as syncope and dyspnea and warned about the use of noncardiac drugs that can prolong the QT interval.

section.label: Proarrhythmia
section.fragment: For type IA or type III drugs, with the possible exception of amiodarone, the corrected QT interval in sinus rhythm should remain below 520 milliseconds.

section.label: Proarrhythmia
section.fragment: During follow-up, serum creatinine, potassium, and magnesium concentrations should be monitored periodically because proarrhythmia is increased by renal insufficiency, which can lead to drug accumulation, hyperkalemia, and hypermagnesemia.

section.label: Proarrhythmia
section.fragment: In comparison, amiodarone is metabolized in the liver and dose adjustment is probably necessary in patients with hepatic dysfunction.

section.label: Bradyarrhythmia
section.fragment: Amiodarone and dronedarone can cause both sinus bradycardia and AV nodal block, with an overall incidence of bradycardic events of about 5 percent.

section.label: Bradyarrhythmia
section.fragment: Sotalol, like other beta blockers, can also cause bradycardia.

section.label: term therapy
section.fragment: This concept was tested in the Flec-SL non-inferiority trial, which randomly assigned 554 patients with persistent AF and who were intended to undergo cardioversion to either four weeks or six months of flecainide (200 to 300 mg per day).

section.label: Concerns about dronedarone
section.fragment: Patients with severe heart failure (HF) (generally those with NYHA class III or IV HF, or those who have been hospitalized with HF in the past four weeks) or those with an ejection fraction of <35 percent should not receive dronedarone.

section.label: Concerns about dronedarone
section.fragment: The Permanent Atrial fibriLLAtion outcome Study (PALLAS) was designed to test the hypothesis that dronedarone would improve major outcomes in 10,000 patients with permanent AF, over 70 percent of whom had New York Heart Association heart failure class I to III or left ventricular systolic dysfunction at baseline.

section.label: Concerns about dronedarone
section.fragment: The study was stopped early (3236 patients enrolled), after a significantly increased risk (Hazard Ratio 2.29, 95% CI 1.34-3.94) of cardiovascular events (cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, stroke and systemic embolism) was observed in the dronedarone arm.

section.label: Concerns about dronedarone
section.fragment: The individual secondary end points of stroke, death from cardiovascular causes, and hospitalization for heart failure were also significantly increased in the dronedarone group.

section.label: Concerns about dronedarone
section.fragment: In addition, the USFDA now recommends that people taking the drug should have an electrocardiogram every three months to make sure that AF has not become permanent.

section.label: Concerns about dronedarone
section.fragment: For patients taking dronedarone, routine monitoring of lung and liver function is not mandated by the USFDA;

section.label: RECOMMENDATIONS OF OTHERS
section.fragment: Our recommendations for the use of antiarrhythmic drugs to maintain sinus rhythm in patients with AF are generally in agreement with the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association/European Society of Cardiology (ACC/AHA/ESC) guidelines on AF and the 2010 European Society of Cardiology guidelines on AF.

section.label: RECOMMENDATIONS OF OTHERS
section.fragment: The 2006 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association/European Society of Cardiology (ACC/AHA/ESC) guidelines recommend propafenone, flecainide, and sotalol as first-line drugs to maintain sinus rhythm after cardioversion in patients without structural heart disease;

section.label: RECOMMENDATIONS OF OTHERS
section.fragment: amiodarone and dofetilide can also be given as second-line agents.

section.label: RECOMMENDATIONS OF OTHERS
section.fragment: These drugs are generally better tolerated and perhaps safer than the class IA drugs, such as quinidine, which were widely used in the past.

section.label: RECOMMENDATIONS OF OTHERS
section.fragment: Because of concerns about toxicity, the ACC/AHA/ESC guidelines recommend that the use of amiodarone as a first-line therapy for maintenance of sinus rhythm should be reserved for patients with heart failure, moderate-to-severe systolic dysfunction, or hypertension with substantial left ventricular hypertrophy.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For those patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) in whom a rhythm-control strategy is chosen, the principal goal is to reduce symptoms by decreasing the frequency and duration of episodes.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: The following points should be kept in mind when considering antiarrhythmic drug therapy to maintain sinus rhythm in patients with AF: Beta blockers are modestly effective in maintaining sinus rhythm and can be tried first in selected patients, such as those without structural heart disease who are concerned about proarrhythmia.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Compared to placebo, amiodarone, sotalol, dofetilide, dronedarone, flecainide, and propafenone are effective for the maintenance of sinus rhythm, but maintenance rates at one year are significantly less than 75 percent.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Amiodarone is consistently more effective than the other antiarrhythmic drugs.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Although a drug may be shown to significantly prolong the time to recurrence of AF in a clinical trial, individual patients may experience no benefit or experience a dramatic reduction in AF frequency.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We make the following recommendations for the choice of antiarrhythmic drug to maintain sinus rhythm in patients with AF.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For patients with no structural heart disease and no apparent risk for drug-induced bradycardia or tachycardia, we suggest flecainide as the preferred antiarrhythmic drug.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For patients with coronary artery disease who do not have advanced heart failure, we suggest dronedarone or sotalol in preference to amiodarone.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Amiodarone is a reasonable choice in patients who prefer its greater efficacy despite its worse extracardiac side-effect profile.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For patients with heart failure, we suggest amiodarone in preference to dofetilide.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Flecainide, propafenone, dronedarone, and sotalol are contraindicated in these patients.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For patients with left ventricular hypertrophy, either amiodarone or dronedarone is generally preferred to other antiarrhythmic agents.

feed.title: Antiarrhythmic drugs to maintain sinus rhythm in patients with atrial fibrillation: Recommendations

section.label: INDICATIONS
section.fragment: There are three settings in which a rhythm control strategy for the maintenance of sinus rhythm should be considered: Persistent symptoms (palpitations, dyspnea, lightheadedness, angina, syncope, and heart failure) despite adequate rate control.

section.label: INDICATIONS
section.fragment: We consider cardioversion to sinus rhythm in most patients, particularly younger patients, with a first-detected episode of atrial fibrillation (AF) in whom the arrhythmia is of recent onset and the risk for recurrence appears to be low.

section.label: INDICATIONS
section.fragment: Maintenance antiarrhythmic drug therapy is not routinely used after cardioversion in patients with newly detected AF.

section.label: Addressing precipitating factors
section.fragment: Maintenance antiarrhythmic drug therapy is not recommended after cardioversion in a patient with a transient or reversible cause (such as cardiac surgery, pericarditis, or pulmonary embolism).

section.label: AV nodal blocker therapy
section.fragment: This therapy is continued while the patient is in sinus rhythm to protect against a rapid ventricular rate (greater than 110 bpm) should AF recur.

section.label: AV nodal blocker therapy
section.fragment: A beta blocker, or rate-slowing calcium channel blocker such as verapamil or diltiazem, is often used if there are no contraindications, since the withdrawal of vagal tone and increase in sympathetic tone with exercise often render digoxin relatively ineffective for controlling the heart rate.

section.label: AV nodal blocker therapy
section.fragment: On the other hand, digoxin is often used in patients with AF associated with systolic heart failure because of its beneficial effect on symptom control.

section.label: AV nodal blocker therapy
section.fragment: Such patients are also typically treated with a beta blocker because of the associated improvement in survival.

section.label: AV nodal blocker therapy
section.fragment: The negative inotropic activity of calcium channel blockers makes them less desirable in such patients.

section.label: AV nodal blocker therapy
section.fragment: Class I antiarrhythmic drugs, such as flecainide, may suppress most, but not all, reentrant circuits.

section.label: Restoration of sinus rhythm
section.fragment: Many patients with AF in whom a rhythm control strategy is chosen will need sinus rhythm restored prior to the initiation of long-term antiarrhythmic drug therapy.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: Amiodarone, dofetilide, flecainide, propafenone, sotalol, and less commonly dronedarone are the drugs we recommend to maintain sinus rhythm.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: The following points regarding antiarrhythmic drugs should be kept in mind in choosing therapy: Compared to other agents, amiodarone is associated with the greatest likelihood of maintaining sinus rhythm, but also with the highest risk of long-term complications.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: Quinidine, procainamide, and disopyramide are no longer recommended for patients with AF, except perhaps in patients with vagally mediated atrial fibrillation (AF), as there are more effective drugs and due to extracardiac side effects as well as the concern about proarrhythmia.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: Beta blockers are modestly effective in maintaining sinus rhythm and can be tried first in selected patients, such as those without structural heart disease who are concerned about proarrhythmia.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: Of course beta blockers may have already been initiated to slow the ventricular rate in AF.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: We believe it is prudent to obtain a two-dimensional echocardiogram to screen for structural heart disease (eg, left ventricular systolic dysfunction, left ventricular hypertrophy, or valvular heart disease).

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: As examples, our experts rarely use dofetilide for paroxysmal AF and infrequently choose dronedarone for persistent AF due to reduced efficacy compared with amiodarone.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: The 2010 European Society of Cardiology and the 2006 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association/European Society of Cardiology guidelines suggest that, because of its long-lasting anticholinergic activity, disopyramide may be considered in patients with vagally-induced AF (eg, occurring most often in athletic young men with slow heart rates during rest or sleep), as long as the patient does not have prostatism or glaucoma.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: For patients with adrenergically-mediated AF (eg, occurring during exercise or other activity), we suggest beta blockers as first-line therapy, followed by sotalol and amiodarone.

section.label: SELECTING AN ANTIARRHYTHMIC DRUG
section.fragment: Antiarrhythmic drugs are associated with a potential for serious adverse side effects, particularly the induction of proarrhythmia.

section.label: AF without structural heart disease
section.fragment: Patients without structural heart disease include those with hypertension who do not have left ventricular hypertrophy.

section.label: AF without structural heart disease
section.fragment: The author and reviewers of this topic generally select flecainide as the first antiarrhythmic drug for these patients due to its relatively good side effect profile, efficacy, and ease of use.

section.label: AF without structural heart disease
section.fragment: In these patients, flecainide, propafenone, amiodarone, dronedarone, sotalol, and dofetilide are superior to placebo for maintaining sinus rhythm.

section.label: AF without structural heart disease
section.fragment: For those patients in whom flecainide will not be used as the preferred agent, the following points can influence the choice of antiarrhythmic drug in patients without structural heart disease: In the Canadian Trial of Atrial fibrillation, AFFIRM, and the SAFE-T randomized trials, amiodarone was more effective than flecainide, propafenone, or sotalol (which have nearly equivalent efficacy to each other), but has a significantly higher rate of adverse side effects.

section.label: AF without structural heart disease
section.fragment: In a meta-analysis of trials where the effect of amiodarone versus dronedarone was estimated with the use of indirect comparison and normal logistic meta-analysis models, amiodarone was found to be more effective in maintaining sinus rhythm, but at the expense of greater drug discontinuation secondary to adverse events.

section.label: AF without structural heart disease
section.fragment: In the EMERALD trial, Dofetilide had a somewhat better efficacy than sotalol.

section.label: AF without structural heart disease
section.fragment: Some cardiologists prefer to use low-dose amiodarone (200 mg per day) in preference to flecainide, sotalol, or dronedarone for two principal reasons: greater efficacy than sotalol and dronedarone, and a very low incidence of torsades de pointes.

section.label: AF associated with structural heart disease
section.fragment: Amiodarone, sotalol, and dofetilide are the most commonly recommended first-line drugs in patients with structural heart disease.

section.label: AF associated with structural heart disease
section.fragment: These drugs (with the exception of dronedarone) were used for initial therapy in almost 70 percent of patients in AFFIRM, 88 percent of whom had organic heart disease and/or hypertension.

section.label: AF associated with structural heart disease
section.fragment: Amiodarone was significantly more effective than sotalol in the CTAF, AFFIRM, and SAFE-T trials.

section.label: AF associated with structural heart disease
section.fragment: However, in SAFE-T, sotalol was as effective as amiodarone in the subgroup of patients with coronary heart disease.

section.label: Coronary heart disease
section.fragment: In patients with coronary heart disease who do not have heart failure, sotalol, dronedarone, dofetilide, and amiodarone are acceptable choices.

section.label: Coronary heart disease
section.fragment: In the Cardiac Arrhythmia Suppression Trial (CAST) of patients with drug-suppressible ventricular premature beats in the year following a myocardial infarction, flecainide increased mortality compared to placebo.

section.label: Coronary heart disease
section.fragment: Although propafenone was not used in CAST and may not have the same potential for proarrhythmia as flecainide and encainide, it cannot be recommended in patients with underlying heart disease.

section.label: Coronary heart disease
section.fragment: The extension of this concern to structural heart disease other than coronary artery disease stems in part from the flecainide clinical and safety database, which was used in a retrospective study demonstrating that the presence of structural heart disease including valvular heart disease, congenital heart disease, and cardiomyopathies lead to an alarming increase in proarrhythmia and death.

section.label: Heart failure
section.fragment: Amiodarone and dofetilide, are used in patients with AF and heart failure (HF) or those with a left ventricular ejection fraction less than 35 percent.

section.label: Heart failure
section.fragment: Our authors and reviewers are more comfortable using dofetilide in this setting with an implantable defibrillator in place or in younger patients with less severe impairment of left ventricular systolic function.

section.label: Heart failure
section.fragment: Sotalol, propafenone, and flecainide should not be used in patients with heart failure, due to studies showing an increase in mortality with these agents.

section.label: Left ventricular hypertrophy
section.fragment: Patients with significant left ventricular hypertrophy (defined as left ventricular wall thickness greater 1.4 cm for the purposes of this discussion) due to hypertension, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, or aortic stenosis have underlying subendocardial ischemia and electrophysiologic abnormalities.

section.label: Left ventricular hypertrophy
section.fragment: Sotalol, flecainide and propafenone are thought to have a significant arrhythmic risk in patients with left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH).

section.label: resistant AF
section.fragment: Some patients are refractory to individual antiarrhythmic agents plus an AV nodal blocker or develop side effects on doses necessary for arrhythmia prevention.

section.label: resistant AF
section.fragment: Although some have suggested that combination antiarrhythmic drug therapy (eg, a class IC agent with sotalol or amiodarone, often in lower doses) may be an alternative, there are limited data to support such an approach and the patient may be exposed to a greater risk of proarrhythmia and other side effects.

section.label: resistant AF
section.fragment: As a result, combination antiarrhythmic drug therapy is not recommended.

section.label: INPATIENT VERSUS OUTPATIENT INITIATION
section.fragment: Outpatient initiation of antiarrhythmic drug therapy with the following agents may be considered: Flecainide or propafenone in patients in sinus rhythm who have no underlying structural heart disease, normal baseline QT intervals, and no profound bradycardia or suspected sinus or atrioventricular (AV) node dysfunction.

section.label: INPATIENT VERSUS OUTPATIENT INITIATION
section.fragment: Amiodarone or dronedarone in selected patients who have no other risk factors for torsades de pointes (eg, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia) or sinus node dysfunction or AV conduction disease.

section.label: INPATIENT VERSUS OUTPATIENT INITIATION
section.fragment: Dronedarone and amiodarone are the only two drugs that can be initiated in outpatients while in atrial fibrillation.

section.label: INPATIENT VERSUS OUTPATIENT INITIATION
section.fragment: Patients with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) represent another group in which outpatient initiation of therapy can be tried, since the ICD provides protection against the risks associated with bradyarrhythmias and tachyarrhythmias.

section.label: INPATIENT VERSUS OUTPATIENT INITIATION
section.fragment: The initiation of antiarrhythmic drugs in patients with paroxysmal AF while they are in sinus rhythm is also associated with some risk.

section.label: INPATIENT VERSUS OUTPATIENT INITIATION
section.fragment: Inpatient initiation with continuous telemetry of higher-risk drugs such as dofetilide and sotalol is typically done over a course of three days, which encompasses five half-lives allowing for achievement of steady-state plasma concentrations.

section.label: AF recurrence
section.fragment: Some patients will elect to continue drug therapy (and, in some cases, occasional cardioversion) because the arrhythmia burden has been substantially reduced as evidenced by episodes that are less frequent, shorter, or associated with milder symptoms.

section.label: AF recurrence
section.fragment: Nonpharmacologic therapies are another option in such patients.

section.label: AF recurrence
section.fragment: If a patient has unacceptable recurrent AF on one antiarrhythmic drug, the drug is discontinued and another (and on rare occasion a third) agent is tried.

section.label: related arrhythmias and mortality
section.fragment: Compared to controls, the use of the class IA antiarrhythmics quinidine and disopyramide (odds ratio 2.39, 95% CI 1.03-5.59) or sotalol (2.47, 95% CI 1.2-5.05) was associated with increased all-cause mortality, whereas the use of amiodarone, dronedarone, and dofetilide was not (odds ratios were not calculated for flecainide or propafenone).

section.label: Proarrhythmia
section.fragment: All of the antiarrhythmic drugs used to maintain sinus rhythm have the potential to increase ectopy or induce or aggravate monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT), torsades de pointes, or ventricular fibrillation (VF);

section.label: Proarrhythmia
section.fragment: In addition to its baseline potential to predispose the patient to proarrhythmia, a drug that is initially safe may become proarrhythmic when the patient develops coronary heart disease or heart failure or is treated with other medications that in combination may be arrhythmogenic.

section.label: Proarrhythmia
section.fragment: Thus, the patient should be alerted to the potential significance of symptoms such as syncope and dyspnea and warned about the use of noncardiac drugs that can prolong the QT interval.

section.label: Proarrhythmia
section.fragment: For type IA or type III drugs, with the possible exception of amiodarone, the corrected QT interval in sinus rhythm should remain below 520 milliseconds.

section.label: Proarrhythmia
section.fragment: During follow-up, serum creatinine, potassium, and magnesium concentrations should be monitored periodically because proarrhythmia is increased by renal insufficiency, which can lead to drug accumulation, hyperkalemia, and hypermagnesemia.

section.label: Proarrhythmia
section.fragment: In comparison, amiodarone is metabolized in the liver and dose adjustment is probably necessary in patients with hepatic dysfunction.

section.label: Bradyarrhythmia
section.fragment: Amiodarone and dronedarone can cause both sinus bradycardia and AV nodal block, with an overall incidence of bradycardic events of about 5 percent.

section.label: Bradyarrhythmia
section.fragment: Sotalol, like other beta blockers, can also cause bradycardia.

section.label: term therapy
section.fragment: This concept was tested in the Flec-SL non-inferiority trial, which randomly assigned 554 patients with persistent AF and who were intended to undergo cardioversion to either four weeks or six months of flecainide (200 to 300 mg per day).

section.label: Concerns about dronedarone
section.fragment: Patients with severe heart failure (HF) (generally those with NYHA class III or IV HF, or those who have been hospitalized with HF in the past four weeks) or those with an ejection fraction of <35 percent should not receive dronedarone.

section.label: Concerns about dronedarone
section.fragment: The Permanent Atrial fibriLLAtion outcome Study (PALLAS) was designed to test the hypothesis that dronedarone would improve major outcomes in 10,000 patients with permanent AF, over 70 percent of whom had New York Heart Association heart failure class I to III or left ventricular systolic dysfunction at baseline.

section.label: Concerns about dronedarone
section.fragment: The study was stopped early (3236 patients enrolled), after a significantly increased risk (Hazard Ratio 2.29, 95% CI 1.34-3.94) of cardiovascular events (cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, stroke and systemic embolism) was observed in the dronedarone arm.

section.label: Concerns about dronedarone
section.fragment: The individual secondary end points of stroke, death from cardiovascular causes, and hospitalization for heart failure were also significantly increased in the dronedarone group.

section.label: Concerns about dronedarone
section.fragment: In addition, the USFDA now recommends that people taking the drug should have an electrocardiogram every three months to make sure that AF has not become permanent.

section.label: Concerns about dronedarone
section.fragment: For patients taking dronedarone, routine monitoring of lung and liver function is not mandated by the USFDA;

section.label: RECOMMENDATIONS OF OTHERS
section.fragment: Our recommendations for the use of antiarrhythmic drugs to maintain sinus rhythm in patients with AF are generally in agreement with the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association/European Society of Cardiology (ACC/AHA/ESC) guidelines on AF and the 2010 European Society of Cardiology guidelines on AF.

section.label: RECOMMENDATIONS OF OTHERS
section.fragment: The 2006 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association/European Society of Cardiology (ACC/AHA/ESC) guidelines recommend propafenone, flecainide, and sotalol as first-line drugs to maintain sinus rhythm after cardioversion in patients without structural heart disease;

section.label: RECOMMENDATIONS OF OTHERS
section.fragment: amiodarone and dofetilide can also be given as second-line agents.

section.label: RECOMMENDATIONS OF OTHERS
section.fragment: These drugs are generally better tolerated and perhaps safer than the class IA drugs, such as quinidine, which were widely used in the past.

section.label: RECOMMENDATIONS OF OTHERS
section.fragment: Because of concerns about toxicity, the ACC/AHA/ESC guidelines recommend that the use of amiodarone as a first-line therapy for maintenance of sinus rhythm should be reserved for patients with heart failure, moderate-to-severe systolic dysfunction, or hypertension with substantial left ventricular hypertrophy.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For those patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) in whom a rhythm-control strategy is chosen, the principal goal is to reduce symptoms by decreasing the frequency and duration of episodes.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: The following points should be kept in mind when considering antiarrhythmic drug therapy to maintain sinus rhythm in patients with AF: Beta blockers are modestly effective in maintaining sinus rhythm and can be tried first in selected patients, such as those without structural heart disease who are concerned about proarrhythmia.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Compared to placebo, amiodarone, sotalol, dofetilide, dronedarone, flecainide, and propafenone are effective for the maintenance of sinus rhythm, but maintenance rates at one year are significantly less than 75 percent.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Amiodarone is consistently more effective than the other antiarrhythmic drugs.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Although a drug may be shown to significantly prolong the time to recurrence of AF in a clinical trial, individual patients may experience no benefit or experience a dramatic reduction in AF frequency.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We make the following recommendations for the choice of antiarrhythmic drug to maintain sinus rhythm in patients with AF.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For patients with no structural heart disease and no apparent risk for drug-induced bradycardia or tachycardia, we suggest flecainide as the preferred antiarrhythmic drug.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For patients with coronary artery disease who do not have advanced heart failure, we suggest dronedarone or sotalol in preference to amiodarone.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Amiodarone is a reasonable choice in patients who prefer its greater efficacy despite its worse extracardiac side-effect profile.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For patients with heart failure, we suggest amiodarone in preference to dofetilide.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Flecainide, propafenone, dronedarone, and sotalol are contraindicated in these patients.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For patients with left ventricular hypertrophy, either amiodarone or dronedarone is generally preferred to other antiarrhythmic agents.

feed.title: Control of ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation: Pharmacologic therapy

section.label: GENERAL PRINCIPLES
section.fragment: The initial management of patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) and a rapid ventricular response involves two decisions: Determining the urgency of initial therapy (eg, intravenous versus oral rate control therapy, and/or immediate versus elective cardioversion).

section.label: GENERAL PRINCIPLES
section.fragment: As an example, a patient for whom rate control may be the appropriate long-term strategy may require urgent cardioversion in the acute setting due to hemodynamic instability.

section.label: GENERAL PRINCIPLES
section.fragment: Selection of an appropriate regimen is guided by an understanding of the determinants of the ventricular rate in AF and a structured method for assessing the adequacy of rate control.

section.label: Determinants of ventricular rate
section.fragment: In most myocardial tissue, the initial depolarizing phase of the action potential (phase 0) is mediated by rapid sodium channels.

section.label: Determinants of ventricular rate
section.fragment: In contrast, in the slow response fibers of the AV node, phase 0 is mediated by an inward calcium current, which uses a kinetically slow channel.

section.label: Rate control goals
section.fragment: Achieving rates similar to those recommended for patients in sinus rhythm with heart disease has been advocated: resting heart rate <=80 beats/min and <=110 beats/min during moderate exercise such as with the six-minute walk.

section.label: Rate control goals
section.fragment: This issue was directly addressed in the RACE II trial, which randomly assigned 614 physically active patients with permanent AF to either a lenient rate control strategy (resting heart rate <110 beats per minute) or a strict rate control strategy (resting heart rate <80 beats per minute and heart rate during moderate exercise <110 beats per minute).

section.label: Rate control goals
section.fragment: The primary outcome was a composite of cardiovascular death, hospitalization for heart failure, and stroke, systemic embolism, bleeding, and life-threatening arrhythmic events.

section.label: Rate control goals
section.fragment: When the data were analyzed from the end of the dose-adjustment phase until the end of follow-up (median 2.9 years), the average heart rates in the lenient control group, strict control group patients who met the target, and strict control group patients who failed to meet the target were significantly different at 93, 72, and 86 beats per minute, respectively.

section.label: Rate control goals
section.fragment: By comparison, mean resting rates in the strict control group were 75+12, 75+12, and 76+14 beats per minute, respectively.

section.label: Rate control goals
section.fragment: Based upon the results of the RACE II trial, we believe that achieving strict heart rate control is not necessary in many physically active patients with AF who are minimally symptomatic.

section.label: Rate control goals
section.fragment: It is important to consider that symptoms may be due to either inadequate rate control or relative bradycardia (eg, in patients with tachy-brady syndrome).

section.label: mediated cardiomyopathy
section.fragment: Persistently increased ventricular rates in AF have been associated with a left ventricular cardiomyopathy.

section.label: mediated cardiomyopathy
section.fragment: Some experts perform an echocardiogram every two to three years in asymptomatic patients with higher average ventricular rates while others do not.

section.label: Urgency of therapy
section.fragment: In a patient with new or recurrent AF with a rapid ventricular response, the intensity of initial therapy depends upon the clinical scenario: Emergent therapy - In patients who are clinically or hemodynamically unstable (eg, myocardial ischemia, pulmonary edema, hypotension) due to AF and a rapid ventricular response, treatment options include intravenous rate control medications and/or immediate cardioversion ).

section.label: Urgency of therapy
section.fragment: In patients with an adequate blood pressure, pharmacologic rate control with intravenous calcium channel blockers or beta blockers may be attempted, while arrangements are made for cardioversion.

section.label: Urgency of therapy
section.fragment: If the patient responds to rate control therapy but remains unstable, an explanation other than AF with a rapid ventricular response should be sought.

section.label: Urgency of therapy
section.fragment: Patients who are chronically managed with a rhythm control strategy can undergo cardioversion if they have been adequately anticoagulated or are considered to have a low thromboembolic risk.

section.label: Rhythm versus rate control
section.fragment: The two main therapeutic strategies in patients with AF are: Rhythm control, which consists of cardioversion, often followed by maintenance of sinus rhythm with arrhythmic drugs.

section.label: Rhythm versus rate control
section.fragment: In the past, many physicians preferred a rhythm control strategy because of presumed improvements in symptoms, hemodynamics, and embolic risk.

section.label: Rhythm versus rate control
section.fragment: As a result, a rate control strategy is now preferred in most asymptomatic patients.

section.label: PHARMACOLOGIC TREATMENT
section.fragment: These agents slow atrioventricular (AV) nodal conduction based upon the following physiologic mechanisms: Blockade of the calcium channel with the nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers verapamil and diltiazem.

section.label: PHARMACOLOGIC TREATMENT
section.fragment: Enhancement of parasympathetic tone with vagotonic drugs, the most important of which is digoxin.

section.label: Beta blockers
section.fragment: Beta blockers are commonly used for both the acute and chronic control of ventricular rates in patients with AF.

section.label: Acute control with beta blockers
section.fragment: Esmolol is a rapidly acting intravenous beta blocker that is metabolized by red blood cell esterase, resulting in a short duration of action (10 to 20 minutes).

section.label: Acute control with beta blockers
section.fragment: The following esmolol regimen is recommended for acute rate control: A bolus of 0.5 mg/kg is infused over one minute, followed by 50 microg/kg per min.

section.label: Chronic beta blocker therapy
section.fragment: There are some data that labetalol is less effective than other beta blockers for reducing heart rate at rest.

section.label: Chronic beta blocker therapy
section.fragment: Beta blockers have additional properties that may make them preferred to other rate control drugs in some AF patients: Patients with chronic heart failure due to systolic dysfunction - A retrospective analysis from the United States Carvedilol Trials Program evaluated 1094 heart failure patients with AF.

section.label: Chronic beta blocker therapy
section.fragment: In addition, there was a trend toward a decrease in the combined end point of death or hospitalization for heart failure.

section.label: Chronic beta blocker therapy
section.fragment: Beta blockers may reduce the incidence of AF recurrence in patients with episodes of AF that are triggered by surges in sympathetic activity.

section.label: Chronic beta blocker therapy
section.fragment: Some of these complications that may be important in patients with AF include: Worsening heart failure.

section.label: Chronic beta blocker therapy
section.fragment: Some patients with paroxysmal AF also have sinus node dysfunction, with the tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome.

section.label: Calcium channel blockers
section.fragment: The nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers verapamil and diltiazem are useful in the management of AF in the absence of preexcitation.

section.label: Clinical cautions
section.fragment: Calcium channel blockers have a number of characteristics that need to be considered when they are administered to patients with AF: The effect on sinoatrial (SA) nodal function is variable.

section.label: Clinical cautions
section.fragment: Although both verapamil and diltiazem have an inhibitory effect on the sinus node, their vasodilator effects cause a reflex release of catecholamines that usually maintains or slightly accelerates the SA nodal rate.

section.label: Clinical cautions
section.fragment: However, patients with the sick sinus syndrome may be particularly sensitive to the effects of calcium channel blockers.

section.label: Clinical cautions
section.fragment: As a result, these drugs should be used with caution in patients with heart failure and in patients taking other negative inotropes, such as beta blockers.

section.label: Clinical cautions
section.fragment: Verapamil interacts with digoxin, resulting in an increase in serum digoxin.

section.label: Clinical cautions
section.fragment: Similar to the digoxin-quinidine interaction, verapamil reduces the renal clearance of digoxin;

section.label: Clinical cautions
section.fragment: In summary, diltiazem and verapamil should not be given to patients with severe heart failure (New York Heart Failure class III or IV), the preexcitation syndrome, or significant hypotension.

section.label: Digoxin
section.fragment: Digoxin slows the ventricular rate during AF primarily by vagotonic inhibition of AV nodal conduction.

section.label: Digoxin
section.fragment: Digoxin is generally less effective for rate control than beta blockers or calcium channel blockers, particularly during exercise when vagal tone is low and sympathetic tone is high.

section.label: Digoxin
section.fragment: For these reasons, digoxin should not be used as a first-line drug for rate control in most settings.

section.label: Left ventricular dysfunction
section.fragment: In patients with heart failure due to systolic dysfunction and AF, digoxin has two potential benefits: reduction in the ventricular rate and improvement in contractility.

section.label: Left ventricular dysfunction
section.fragment: However, beta blockers, if tolerated, are now a standard component of therapy for all patients with heart failure due to systolic dysfunction.

section.label: Left ventricular dysfunction
section.fragment: Thus, in patients with left ventricular dysfunction, the use of digoxin is limited to the following settings: Patients who do not achieve rate control targets on beta blockers alone.

section.label: Left ventricular dysfunction
section.fragment: Patients in whom digoxin would be added for improved control of heart failure symptoms independent of AF.

section.label: Left ventricular dysfunction
section.fragment: Many such patients will already be treated with a beta blocker, and care must be taken to avoid excessive bradycardia.

section.label: Amiodarone
section.fragment: Amiodarone is commonly used to maintain sinus rhythm in AF patients in whom a rhythm control strategy is chosen.

section.label: Amiodarone
section.fragment: However, amiodarone can also slow the ventricular rate in patients who remain in AF.

section.label: Amiodarone
section.fragment: In one study, for example, intravenous amiodarone (7 mg/kg), flecainide, or placebo was given to 98 patients with recent onset AF (0.5 to 72 hours).

section.label: Amiodarone
section.fragment: In addition, in critically ill patients, amiodarone may be less likely to cause systemic hypotension than intravenous diltiazem.

section.label: Amiodarone
section.fragment: We agree with this assessment and recommend that patients treated with amiodarone receive careful follow-up, including monitoring for know side effects.

section.label: COMPARATIVE EFFICACY
section.fragment: Thus, it is particularly important to assess heart rate with exertion in patients treated with digoxin alone.

section.label: COMPARATIVE EFFICACY
section.fragment: In a small crossover study of 12 patients with chronic AF, patients were treated for two-week intervals with five different drug regimens: digoxin 0.25 mg daily, diltiazem-CD 240 mg daily, atenolol 50 mg daily, digoxin plus diltiazem, and digoxin plus atenolol.

section.label: AFFIRM trial
section.fragment: Patients initially treated with a beta blocker were significantly less likely than those treated with calcium channel blockers or digoxin to have their drug regimen changed.

section.label: AFFIRM trial
section.fragment: beta blockers were more commonly used in patients with coronary disease, calcium channel blockers were more often given to patients with pulmonary disease and to women, while digoxin was used more often in patients with cardiomyopathy and in nonwhite patients.

section.label: AFFIRM trial
section.fragment: Only 361 (18 percent) of the patients assigned to the rate control strategy had an initial assessment of the adequacy of rate control at rest and with exertion.

section.label: AFFIRM trial
section.fragment: This is because many patients spontaneously reverted to sinus rhythm (and therefore, rate control could not be assessed), and also because of the limited number of patients in atrial fibrillation (AF) who had heart rate assessed with exertion.

section.label: Systematic review
section.fragment: However, the following observations were noted: Diltiazem, verapamil, and most beta blockers (atenolol, metoprolol, timolol, pindolol, and nadolol) were all effective in reducing the ventricular rate during rest and exercise.

section.label: Systematic review
section.fragment: The beta blockers labetalol, xamoterol, and celiprolol were less effective at rest, but did reduce ventricular rates during exercise.

section.label: Systematic review
section.fragment: The combination of digoxin with a beta blocker or calcium channel blocker reduced heart rate both at rest and with exertion.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: The following summary and recommendations are in general agreement with the 2006 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association/European Society of Cardiology guidelines on atrial fibrillation (AF) . This discussion applies to AF patients in whom a chronic rate control strategy has been chosen, or to any AF patient requiring acute rate control.

section.label: Acute rate control
section.fragment: In such patients, we suggest the following approach: In patients without significant heart failure or hypotension, we suggest intravenous beta blockers or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers . Intravenous diltiazem, using the regimen described above, is our preferred drug in this setting.verapamil or intravenous beta blockers such as metoprolol, propranolol, or esmolol are reasonable alternatives.

section.label: Acute rate control
section.fragment: However, in selected patients who do not have hypotension or significant left ventricular dysfunction, these classes may be used together, and in some cases all three agents (ie, a beta blocker, a calcium channel blocker, and digoxin) may be necessary to achieve adequate rate control.

section.label: Chronic rate control
section.fragment: For patients who continue with unacceptable symptoms at this goal, an attempt should be made to see if a lower goal lessens symptoms.

section.label: Chronic rate control
section.fragment: Beta blockers are preferred in patients with coronary heart disease, heart failure due to systolic dysfunction, and in patients in whom the ventricular rate increases inappropriately during exercise.

section.label: Chronic rate control
section.fragment: In the first two settings, beta blockers improve patient survival.

section.label: Chronic rate control
section.fragment: Despite these advantages, beta blockers are contraindicated or relatively contraindicated in some patients, and others cannot tolerate the side effects.

section.label: Chronic rate control
section.fragment: A nondihydropyridine calcium channel blocker is preferred in patients with chronic lung disease and in patients who do not tolerate a beta blocker.

section.label: Chronic rate control
section.fragment: Among the calcium channel blockers, verapamil has a somewhat greater blocking effect on the AV node than diltiazem, and the choice between these drugs is often dictated by side effects.

section.label: Chronic rate control
section.fragment: Diltiazem may be preferred in patients with mild heart failure if a beta blocker is contraindicated or not tolerated.

section.label: Combination therapy
section.fragment: Although some patients may not tolerate both a beta blocker and a calcium channel blocker (eg, those with left ventricular systolic dysfunction or hypotension), the combination can be tried in most patients.

feed.title: Antithrombotic therapy to prevent embolization in atrial fibrillation

section.label: PATIENTS WITH VALVULAR HEART DISEASE
section.fragment: Many, but not all, of the major clinical trials of antithrombotic therapy and subsequent meta-analyses have excluded patients with any type of prosthetic heart valves, those with mitral stenosis, and those with decompensated valvular heart disease who were likely to require valve replacement in the near future.

section.label: PATIENTS WITH VALVULAR HEART DISEASE
section.fragment: Based on these studies, the newer anticoagulants should not be prescribed for these patients.

section.label: PATIENTS WITH VALVULAR HEART DISEASE
section.fragment: Some patients with valvular lesions (without heart failure) such as mitral valve prolapse, non-rheumatic mitral regurgitation, or aortic valve lesions have been enrolled in the clinical trials of the newer anticoagulants.

section.label: PATIENTS WITH VALVULAR HEART DISEASE
section.fragment: These trials also likely included a few patients (with or without heart failure) with severe valvular lesions who were not scheduled to undergo valve replacement.

section.label: PATIENTS WITH VALVULAR HEART DISEASE
section.fragment: Until further evidence is available, we believe these newer drugs can be considered for these patients.

section.label: MECHANISM OF THROMBOEMBOLISM
section.fragment: The mechanisms leading to an increased risk of thrombus, embolism, and stroke in atrial fibrillation (AF) are multiple and closely interact with each other.

section.label: MECHANISM OF THROMBOEMBOLISM
